abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Sector
            Development Project for Sierra Leone were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was high, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Grantee performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: projects
            designed for post-conflict and fragile states need to
            anticipate that implementation and disbursements will be
            slow initially. The Global Partnership for Education (GPE)
            three year implementation requirements should be
            reconsidered, particularly in post conflict countries. A
            strong government project implementation team must be in
            place prior to project effectiveness and remain in place
            throughout project implementation. Strong bank supervision
            with knowledge of bank procedures as well as bank staff
            based in post-conflict countries with low capacity is
            essential for ensuring the implementation of bank-supported
            projects. Future school construction should include more
            capacity building and support in bank procurement methods,
            but should also be managed closer to the community level
            with more appropriate contract management and supervision
            arrangements, and with funds provided directly to local
            governments or communities to pay contractors. Projects
            designed within a context of ongoing decentralization should
            include an initial period of adjustment, as capacity cannot
            be built before but it is actually supported and built
            during implementation. This is especially important for
            post-conflict countries.
